title: Why didn't Finland get absorbed into the USSR? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well Soviets tried it first by force: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_War After winter war, there was Continuation war: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuation_War After all the warring a big price was paid and peace was made. Soviets got actually pretty strong foot in the door in the way of military troops and all kinds of officials, so they had very good idea what was going on here in Finland.  Although Finland remained sovereign, at times the decision making wasn’t very independent due to the Soviet influence. Even so politicians and especially leaders who nurtured good relations with the Soviet Union played their part in retaining independence. Most notable figure here is probably Finnish president Urho Kekkonen As long as Soviet Union existed, it remained as the big deal in Finnish politics.

No need to after the 1939–40 war, and the 1944 aftermath in WW2. Finland surrendered the land the USSR wanted when it exited WW2, and at the same time, from the 1939–40 war, the Soviets realized that permanently holding Finland would take a lot of work.
